The changes would allow Japanese troops to fight abroad for the first time since World War Two. The legislation has already been passed by Japan's lower house and is likely to be approved next week. The change in the pacifist constitution, which dates back to 1947, provides a legal rationale for a more assertive military posture in the Asia-Pacific.

The U.S. military is already in Japan for the war games, which involve more than 160,000 troops from the U.S. Army and Marine Corps as well as their Allies.

The Pentagon said last month that the exercises would focus heavily on anti-terrorism defense and include war games involving an attack by North Korean forces on a U.S. or South Korean ally.

According to Japanese media reports, the legislation would open the door to troops from other friendly nations taking part in the large joint exercises.

Japan's neighbors China and South Korea both see the U.S.-led military drills as provocation.

The aim is to provide a benchmark for the cost of the disease, which costs the NHS and social care in England an estimated £9bn a year, and assess the feasibility and acceptability of recruitment. The cost will also be compared against how effective dementia detection can be in primary care.

A pilot study in 2010 showed that one-in-five people with mild cognitive impairment had progressed into Alzheimer's; that the time between the original and follow-up diagnoses was on average six years and that a one-in-three chance that the symptoms are temporary and reversible.

It also found that the diagnosis of dementia in primary care was effective but that a high workload and workload variability in GPs affected their accuracy.

raw_results.original: Parts of the NHS in England and Wales have lobbied for a change to immigration rules to allow more foreign nurses to come to work in the UK. The government said the move was a temporary measure. It is asking an independent committee that advises on migration for further guidance about how long it should last. Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt said: "Safe staffing across all our hospitals and care homes is a crucial priority. "The temporary changes announced today will ensure the NHS has the nurses it needs to deliver the highest standards of care without having to rely on rip-off staffing agencies that cost the taxpayer billions of pounds a year." The announcement comes after leading NHS figures warned that "stringent" immigration rules are preventing them from getting enough nurses on wards in time for winter. The heads of 10 leading trusts, along with the NHS Employers organisation, wrote to the home secretary to say patients are being put at risk. They argue operations might be cancelled unless nursing is listed as an occupation with official shortages.

Parts of the NHS in England and Wales have lobbied for a change to immigration rules to allow more foreign nurses to come to work in the UK. The call has become a political battleground at a time when the NHS is struggling against falling morale among staff and increasing demand for services.

The calls for a change come amid a growing shortage of nurses in the UK – there are currently 100 vacancies for every 100 UK nursing placements in England. And they are driven by the needs of the health service which is now experiencing a shortage of some 16,000 nurses and midwives across the country. The numbers of nurses and midwives have been falling in recent years, with the issue now “at crisis point” as more EU nationals apply to come to work in the UK.

raw_results.original: The Manx mother of Leo Keefe, who lives in Spain, said she was "in shock" after an anonymous donor contributed tens of thousands of pounds to her son's cause. The four-year-old has been battling SPNET - an aggressive type of brain cancer - for the last 17 months. Mrs Keefe has been told proton beam therapy (PBT) is Leo's "last chance". PBT is a type of radiation treatment that uses protons rather than X-rays to treat cancer and is not available in the UK, Isle of Man or Spain. The NHS currently pays for some children from the UK to go abroad for treatment - these are decided on a case-by-case basis. Leo does not qualify because he does not live in the UK. Mrs Keefe discovered the £150,000 fundraising target had been reached whilst at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool, where Leo is awaiting surgery on two brain tumours.

The Manx mother of Leo Keefe, who lives in Spain, said she was "in shock" after an anonymous donor contributed tens of thousands of pounds to help him move countries to live with his dad.

They used a box to contain the snake, which is believed to be a juvenile Middle American smooth-scaled racer. The snake was taken to the charity's animal rescue centre in Cardonald, Glasgow, where staff have named it Furtivo - Spanish for sneaky. raw_results.original: There were 297,539 donors aged 17 to 34 in 2001, and now there are 237,520. Research by NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) suggests many young people are either too busy or daunted to donate. Only 4% of eligible donors give blood, and most of these are above the age of 40. Just 14% of those who donate regularly are aged below 30. The poll, of more 1,700 people across the country and 1,000 current NHSBT donors, suggests fear and ignorance, as well as time pressures, may be to blame. One in 10 young people aged 18 to 24 said they were too busy, even though nearly three-quarters said everyone who met blood-donation criteria should give blood. More than a third of the 184 people falling into the "young" age bracket said they did not donate because they had a fear of needles, while about a fifth said it was because they did not know where to go.

Ayeeshia Jane Smith died of a tear to her heart in Burton-upon-Trent, Staffordshire, in May 2014. Post-mortem analysis confirmed that her death from “sudden unexpected death not otherwise specified” (SUDNoD) was due to a ruptured aortic aneurysm.

She was just five weeks out from the date of her 30th birthday. The cause of her death was entirely preventable. She lived life as normally as possible – as far as the facts of her life would allow – but her risk of a cardiac event remained very high. She did not realise the risks that she ran until they struck.

Aneurysms affect more women than men, and most commonly occur in a section of the thoracic aorta that connects the heart to the main blood vessel trunk. The risk of developing an aneurysm is relatively low in young adults – one in 10,000.1
